Row.Text: 【译者注：正在翻译，这也太长了草……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In the aftermath of the fall of the Sasanians, Iran saw influxes of a multitudes of peoples from Georgians to Turkmen to Arabs to Mongols. Ordinarily, a subjugated nation would have it's culture overwritten by it's dominators, but the Persian Culture proved pervasive enough to not only endure but to change the cultures of their overlords. The fledgeling Islamic empires adopted Persian courtly practices and philosophic principles. The Turkmen tribes saw themselves mutated in the Iranian practices, giving rise to Turco-Persian Tradition - a tradition that was commonplace not only through all of the Iranian Empires, but also the Seljuk, Ottoman, and Mamluk empires (a form of this persisting in the Republic of Turkey and the Islamic Republic of Iran). The Mongol invaders and the Timurids saw themselves renouncing their steppe way of life and becoming Iranian Kings. In a way, all of these foreigners were made to serve Persia, no matter how many Persians they massacred or how much woe they brought to the land.

While Iran influenced its overlords - the Caliphates, the Ghaznavids, the Seljuks, the Khwarezmids, the Mongols, the Timurids, and the Koyunlu tribes - they were in turn permuted. Zoroastrianism was replaced by Sunni Islam (albeit very slowly). And Iran would not have a native rule again until 1501 with the establishment of the Safavid empire by Shah Ismail.

Ismail hailed from a Turkmen tribe (part of the Qizilbash) and claimed direct descent from Hasan the Tall (also translated as Hasan the Long. Get your mind out of the gutter). His father, Sheikh Haydar, was the Grandmaster of the Safaviyya Sufi Order within the Twelver branch of Shi'a Islam. While the direct beliefs of the Twelvers are important for this, it is their practices that are. They believed, like all other Shi'a, that the first three caliphs stole the Caliphal office from the fourth Caliph: Ali, the son of Muhammad. The Safaviyya order also claimed direct descent from Muhammad (though that is likely a blatant lie) and therefore it was more than a little personal. In addition, their common practices were to curse the first three Caliphs (uhh...), destroy Sunni Mosques (wait...), defile Sunni graves (maybe you shouldn't...), And burn effigies of the first three Caliphs (GUYS WHAT). As such, Ismail grew up as a fanatic of Twelverism and made it his mission to destroy all of Sunni Islam.

When Sheikh Haydar was killed during a siege against the Ak Koyunlu Turkmen (literally meaning "White Sheep" Turks. Turns out that when your people are shepherds, they tend to like sheep. Get your mind out of the gutter), Ismail embarked on a mission of vengeance against the Ak Koyunlu, utterly destroying them with the help of his Qizilbash tribesmen despite being outnumber. Seeing how easy it was to dominate northwestern Iran, he carried on conquering and destroying mosques along the way - the whole time being treated as an invincible demigod by his Qizilbash. He proclaimed himself the Shahanshah of Iran and the Shah of Azerbaijan in 1501, and additionally went on a campaign of transforming Iran from being 90% Sunni to totally Twelver Shia. It's telling that Iran remains a majority Twelver nation (albeit slightly more mellow, and much less likely to burn effigies) to this day.

In 1512, Shah Ismail was finally defeated and retired to a life of miserable inebriation, but the Safavid dynasty that he founded managed to endure until 1736 despite this defeat. He was succeeded by his son, Tahmasp I, who enjoyed the longest reign of any Iranian Shah.

When Tahmasp came to the throne, the empire was threatened by opponents inside and out: Ismail’s reliance on Qizilbash forces resulted in the entrenchment of a feuding Qizilbash nobility that sapped the central power of the Shah, and the glaring lack of a force that could stand up to gunpowder infantry. Speaking of which, the Ottomans were still a very hostile force on Iran’s border, and though Sultan Selim had died, his son was Suleiman the Lawgiver, and a lion in his own right. Not to mention the Uzbeks in the far east. More worryingly – when Tahmasp ascended the throne, he was a child at 10 years old, and was dueled over by those very Qizilbash Nobles for the right to be the regent and therefore control the country.

After nine years of various Qizilbash being executed and taking out their personal issues on each other, and a 14 year old shah ordering the general massacre of an entire tribe, Tahmasp executed the last of his viziers that was plotting against him (his name was Husayn) and ascended the throne in his own right. Much of Tahmasp’s reign was international treaties, placating the Ottoman Empire through the Peace of Amasya and dividing the caucuses and the middle east between the two. He also founded a new force of soldiers – creatively named the “Third Force” - that would cut away at the power of the Qizilbash, enabling his successors to do away with them and establish a proper meritocratic kingdom (a new trend in those days). After properly fixing relations with the Ottoman and Mughal Empires, peaces that would last for 30 years, he also encouraged the rug industry in order to bolster the Iranian economy once more. This would be carried on by his successors, particularly Abbas the Great – replacing the powers of the Qizilbash with Ghulam (slaves) that made up the new positions. Most of these people came from the Caucuses, which would persist until the end of the Qajar dynasty.

Unfortunately, most of these following monarchs were ineffectual, weak, and more interested in women and drink than in ruling Iran. The primary exception to this was Shah Abbas the Great, who became legendary for reasserting Iran’s power by defeating the Uzbeks and Ottomans, then by punishing disloyal Georgian provinces, and then dislodging the Portuguese from the Persian gulf. It was under him that Iran finally ascended to the status of a world power – equal in might to its Ottoman Archrival. Iran experienced a flourishing of architecture and fine arts under his reign, in addition to partnerships with the Dutch East India Company and diplomatic missions to the West (Not to mention is One-Uppage of Tahmasp’s Three Decade reign by having a Four Decade reign). This Safavid Renaissance would never be seen again following his reign. Following him (and his brightest successor – Abbas II in 1666), Safavid Iran would lose its newly-acquired world power status, and slip into a state of near-permanent decay.

It would take nearly a hundred years of attrition before the Safavids were finally overthrown. Iran had to face the new Russian Empire to their North, and the ascendant Mughals in addition to their old enemies – the Uzbeks and the Ottomans. Astrakhan was lost, and the Mughals expanded into Afghanistan. To add insult to injury, the very same ties with the Dutch East India company were used to take control of Iranian trade routes (though Iranian Merchants did enter North and Central Europe because of it) and drain the Safavids of their crucial wealth. Raids were launched on all sides, but what truly ended the Safavids was a warlord named Nader Afshar.

The Turkic Warlord from Khorasan (no relation), seemed a Second Alexander, and has since been deemed the Last Great Asian Conqueror. This is because he found every single ass to kick in the region, and then kicked them all. His rise to power over the region was meteoric, reasserting the power that Shah Ismail and Shah Abbas displayed centuries prior, being completely undefeated for the majority of his rule. Famously, he invaded the Mughal Empire to finance another war with the Ottomans and defeated the numerically superior Mughal army in under three hours. Then he sacked Delhi, and on the way back he easily conquered all the Uzbek khaganates. Nader singlehandedly defeated every single one of Iran’s rivals, until he came to Dagestan. An assassination attempt was made, and was followed by a number of pricey guerrilla wars. He began to lose battles and go mad and ill. Another assassination attempt meant he blinded his sons – disallowing them to rule Iran. He was finally assassinated in 1747, and Iran fell into chaos until 1796, as a number of dynasties (including the Zand dynasty) vied for power over Iran. After the last Zand king was defeated, the Safavids were briefly reinstated for the sole purpose of handing the Office of Shahanshah to the new Qajar dynasty.

Under the Qajars, Iran briefly reasserted Iranian power over the Caucasus (which seems to be a trend – they’ll be trying again any day now), and faced off against the Russians. But this ended poorly for them as they lost these territories to the Russians after two losing wars. The ultimate consequence of this was a massive influx of Muslim refugees (terrifying, I know). A number of mass expulsions of Muslims into Turkey and Iran occurred throughout the Qajar period.

At the same time, the Qajars were primarily concerned with reform and modernization, that in all truth they did quite poorly. A number of diplomatic missions were made to the west (again), while the government only barely avoided total bankruptcy through slashing budgets. Efforts were made to train administrators in modern techniques, as well as begin setting up education systems. However, these reforms angered various nobles who had been excluded, and so they formed a coalition against him and eventually succeeded in having Nasser al-Din Shah Qajar assassinated. The crown passed on, and the reform halted as the new shah took out more debt and self off more concessions in exchange for his lavish lifestyle.

The Shah utterly failed to respond to this crisis, and in July of 1909, the Shah was forced to set up a parliament in a Constitutional Revolution. The discovery of oil in the nation the previous year became a point of contention in the United Kingdom and Imperial Russia’s Great Game, where the nation was divided into spheres of interest. The First World War saw the nation occupied by British, Ottomans, and Russian forces. Fortunately for the Iranians, two of those three occupiers collapsed into revolution by the end of the war, and the third one failed at setting up a protectorate in the region. A military coup was launched from a member of the Persian Cossack Brigade – Reza Shah Pahlavi – and a new dynasty came to power in Iran.

Reza Shah’s sixteen year rule from 1925 to 1941 was characterized by sweeping reforms at a breakneck pace, but through the use of militarism and nationalism. Initially he branded himself as the Iranian Ataturk, setting up a secular authoritarian government. However, the corruption and oppression in place under his rule made Iran a police state. The new, secular laws angered much of the devout Muslims and clergy – going much farther than his Turkish example. Tension came to a brink in 1935, with riots being held in Mashhad. It was quelled by Imperial troops.

After fears that Iran might be occupied during the Second World War, the Tehran Declaration as issued by the allied powers that it would remain free. Though the Soviets did not withdraw from Iran until 1946, this was largely respected. Some elections were held, but when the prime minister, Mohammed Mosaddeq, attempted to nationalize the British oil industry, there was a coup organized by the U.S. to remove him. IT was from that point until 1979 that Iran was ruled as an Autocratic state, though it did initiate a series of reforms in another effort to modernize the country. This encited even more Islamic backlash, and a revolution was staged in 1979, where the Shah was overthrown and Iran was remade into an Islamic republic. Though it has made more moderate moves since then, it has remained one of the more extreme states of the world, subscribing to a very radical version of Islamic law.

【译者注：正在翻译……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A divan, originally a word used for army registrars and payrolls but later metonymed out seventeen degrees to mean specific high government offices (and later long, cushioned furniture), is a department or ministry run by council used by Islamic Empires. They had a variety of uses, originally mainly for bookkeeping and timekeeping, but made more elaborate during the Abbasid Caliphate. The growth of these councils came alongside the vizier, an officer used to coordinate the government that the divans helped to establish. During the Abbasid period, these divans were usually short-lived and would be used for very specific reasons. For example, the first main divan was a department to organize the division of confiscated properties from the Umayyads after the Abbasids overthrew them.
The laws overseen by the divan were extensions of Sharia and Kanun law, though it mostly considered administrative matters rather than actual civic lawmaking.

As time went on, the divans became more seated and more regional. The Seljuk period saw the Seljuk sultan often on campaign, so the Grand Vizier began to take over the more civic and religious duties of the state. For this, he created a Supreme Divan to oversee civic, military, and religious duties. This was then divided into chanceries, treasuries, judicial courts, religious courts, army offices, and even once a postal office. Local divans were also formed to oversee the provincial budget and defense, as well as management of taxation, land confiscation, redress of grievances, and religious endowments.

Seljuq sultans and Iranian Shahs tended to confiscate lands from nobles (the act of confiscation, of course, requiring divans. The regranting of land to other families also required divans) who were unable to pay their taxes (divans needed, of course, for collecting taxes for the state treasury, the army treasury, and the sultan’s personal treasury), leading to the aristocracies’ grasps on their lands being very unstable. In response, they would “donate” their holdings to nearby religious groups – the donations being called a waqf (and of course, the donations required the creation of yet more divans). This way, they were able to hold onto their holdings with less chance of their ruler (or their local divan) coming in and stealing it from them.

It was through this convoluted bureaucracy that the divan became nearly synonymous with byzantine meritocracy running a state – viziers upon viziers being necessary to oversee yet more viziers running the state. What resulted was a very thorough and robust form of government that served the Iranians deep into the modern era.

【译者注：正在翻译……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Following the disastrous battle of Chaldiran, it became very clear that the Iranian army needed to move away from their ancient equestrian tradition and to a more modern gunpowder army. As a result, Shah Abbas created a force of musketeer called the Tofangchi (literally “Men armed with Tofang,” a light musket) out of their former forces of Ghulams. Approximately 12,000 of the 40,000 Ghulam soldiers were given muskets and therefore made into tofangchi, alongside a number of other military reforms such as the marginalization of Qizilbash tribesmen and the formation of an artillery corps. These tofangchi soldiers were made up of Georgian, Circassian, Armenian, and Turkic provincials, and became the new backbone of the Persian Army.

A standard Tofangshi was equipped with a standard flintlock musket, similar to European models, as well as a long dagger known as a Khanjar and a Shamshir. In close combat, the shamshirs and the Khanars would be used with brutal success. They were additional dressed in blue tunics and red trousers, and a tall hat.

While the Safavid dynasty is remembered in the west as part of the Trio of Gunpowder Empires, this is an oversimplification. In reality, Iran’s gunpowder forces were the weakest of those among the major Islamic empires, with the tofangchi being inferior to Ottoman Janissaries and the Iranian Artillery being inferior to that of the Mughals (the Iranians were incapable of making artillery without European assistance, and therefore the artillery corps was the weakest of the branches of their army). The Iranians usually considered the infantry to be secondary to the cavalry. Nevertheless, it was through commitment that Iran managed to make something of the tofangchi, using their bureaucratic skill to ensure that the cream of the crop, as they say, always rose to the top.

During the reign of Nader, the best of the Tofangchi would be promoted to leading their whole regiment, and to join the corps of Jazayerchi – men with a much heavier caliber musket. It was only during Nader’s reign that the reforms of Abbas were completed and the Iranian Tofangchi finally became a force to be reckoned with.

【译者注：正在翻译，这也太长了草……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Ismail originated from a Turkic Tribe in Azerbaijan called the Qizilbash, or more accurately written ‘Kızılbaşlar’ (“Red Heads”. In fact, Ismail was red headed himself. Enigma, JFD, and Leugi didn’t believe me either). Claiming descent from Hasan the Long himself, Ismail very quickly began to conquer nearby lands in order to avenge the death of his father, Haydar, who had been killed during a siege in Dagestan (currently a part of Russia). Afterwards, he decided that there was no reason to stop there since conquering was apparently so easy, and by July of 1501 he managed to conquer Tabriz. He them proclaimed himself the Shah of Azerbaijan and the Shahanshah of Iran, and proceeded to proclaim Twelver Shi’ism the official state religion.

At this point in time, Iran had been 90% Sunni, much like most of the rest of the Muslim world, and was therefore influenced strongly by the Ottoman Sultanate – which was at the time wrestling for control of the title of “Preeminent Muslim Power” with the Mamluks. Ismail’s mission to not only forcibly convert Iran to Twelver Shia (which involved ritually cursing the first three Caliphs, abolishing Sunni Sufi orders and seizing their property, and forcing Sunni ulama to either convert, die, or run away) but the complete and totally destruction of Sunni Islam. He very quickly conquered Iran as well as other outlying regions, destroying Sunni mosques, massacring Sunnis, defacing Sunni graves, and burning effigies of the first three Caliphs all the while.

It was during Ismail’s reign that an alliance between the Ulama (Islamic Clerical) class and the merchant community was formed, since the ownership of property was very insecure under Ismail’s reign. Because of a loophole where the lands owned by Ulama were safe from being confiscated as long as some percentage of the profits went to religious institutions, a number of merchants openly donated these lands to the clerics so they could split the profits. Soon, these clerics would gain full ownership of these lands, becoming a powerful new group of landowners.

When he was not conquering literally everything in sight, Ismail was also a passionate poet, writing under the name Khataii, meaning “He who Sinned.” His works contributed greatly to both Persian and Azerbaijani Islamic literature as well as the Azerbaijani language as a whole, and also assisted in the conversion of Iran to Shia Islam, but few manuscripts still survive. It is reported that most of his poetry was concerned with the topic of Mystical Love.

By 1510, he had conquered all of Iran, as well as a number of outlying territories and Eastern Anatolia in addition to forcing the Georgian kingdoms of Kartli and Kakheti to vassalage. As he garnered his reputation of Invincible Demigod Conqueror, his repeated offenses against the Sunni faith continued to invoke the wrath of the then-prince Selim I of the Ottoman Empire, who was a Sunni Fanatic. To boot, Ismail caused a Shi’ite rebellion in the Ottoman Empire, which was put down. Immediately upon taking his throne, Selim ordered the execution of thousands of Qizilbash in an act of zealotry and vengeance, and began a war against Ismail.

Initially, the war with the Ottomans began with an exchange of belligerent letters, which culminated in the Shah accusing Selim of being a drug addict. After a Persian envoy was torn to pieces, and the Safavids being denounced as heretics that were to be embargoed posthaste, Selim began his march into Iranian territory.

Though Ismail initially considered attacking the Ottomans directly, he settled for a more scorched-earth policy until they finally engaged each other on 23 August 1514 at the Battle of Chaldiran. The Ottomans were equipped with gunpowder arms and janissaries in addition to a large number of artillery. Ismail relied on his tried-and-true Qizilbash. Though it initially looked like the Ottomans were going to be defeated, the Artillery was finally set up and the carts the artillery were wheeled in on were hastily used as cover for the janissary corps. The thundering of rifles and cannons spooked the Qizilbash horses so they would no longer obey the command of their masters. The Iranians attempted to attack the wings in order to avoid the artillery onslaught, but the Turkish guns proved highly maneuverable. The Iranian army was decimated, and Selim put to death all the forces that did not have the good sense to flee. Ismail – wounded – barely managed to escape, but not without losing his sword and armor on the field.

Following the disaster at the Battle of Chaldiran, Selim ransacked the Iranian capital of Tabriz, looting the entire sum of the Persian treasury (including everything that Ismail spent the previous thirteen years winning), Ismail’s favorite two wives, and his entire harem. Selim did not stay long in the Iranian capital for a variety of reasons, but the damage was done. When Ismail returned, he had not only utterly lost his reputation of invulnerability but he was a broken man. He descended into alcoholic misery, and withdrew from the affairs of war and state. Shah Ismail finally died in 1524, outliving Selim by four years, with his followers fractured and warring and his empire losing many territories to its surroundings, though it and the idea of a unified Iran would persist for many centuries after his death up to the present day.

【译者注：正在翻译，这也太长了草……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Qizilbash, or more accurately written ‘Kızılbaşlar’ (literally meaning “Redheads,” as apparently even the middle east has sexy soulless gingers), were a group of Turkmen tribes that lived in Iranian Azerbaijan and Dagestan, as well as the Caucuses and Eastern Anatolia in general. Much like their “fellow” Turkic tribes, they would often have tribal rivalries and feuds, and were expert horsemen. They subscribed to the Twelver branch of Shi’a Islam, which believed in Twelve divinely-ordained leaders… and that the first three caliphs stole the Caliphal office from Ali, who ended up being the fourth caliph. As a result, they advocated the destruction of Sunni Mosques, defiling of Sunni graves, and the burning of effigies of the first three caliphs. Though Twelver Shi’a Islam has become the most common type of Shi’a (for reasons very bloodily shown below), it is important to note that it has since become much less violent.

Shah Ismail was born into a Qizilbash tribe as the son of Sheikh Haydar, a Grandmaster of the Safaviyya Sufi order of Twelver Shia (guess where his empire got its name). It was during a vengeance war that the Qizilbash became very loyal followers of the godlike Ismail, who had made a name for himself for being an invincible warlord. Though the Qizilbash were a coalition of turkic tribes, they set aside their tribal rivalries during Ismail’s reign, regarding him as a god, and therefore were classified rather politely as “extremists” by more orthodox Iranians.

Ismail brought the Qizilbash on the first decade of his campaigns, easily defeating opponents that he was outnumbered against, carrying him to defeating the Ak Koyunlu confederation that had killed his father. He later utterly crushed an Uzbek army, and continued to expand his realm with the help of these horsemen. As he succeeded, so too did the Qizilbash. After every victory, a Qizilbash general would be put in charge of the newly acquired provinces, and a Qizilbash was made the grand vizier. However, their success made people wary, and even Shah Ismail began to curb their influence over the throne. Now regarding the redheads as powerhungry and untrustworthy, Ismail replaced the Qizilbash grand vizier with an ethnic Iranian one.

As Iran had a millennia-long and well-respected cavalry tradition, the Qizilbash was seen as the ultimate warrior, carrying the day at every battle under their supreme Shah. They were fanatically loyal to their Shah, who was hellbent on destroying all of Sunni Islam. With their aid, he organized the Shahkulu Rebellion within the Ottoman Empire, nearly overthrowing it in favor of a pro-Safavid local government. Unfortunately for Ismail, this rebellion ultimately failed due to the rise of the even more fanatical Yavuz Sultan Selim. This rebellion was used as pretext for a massacre of thousands of Qizilbash, and later as Casus Belli for war against Iran.

After a brief exchange of poetry and opium (don’t ask), and a very-not-brief scorched earth campaign by Ismail, the two armies met on the fields of Chaldiran, in the Northwest of Iran. The Safavids brought their cavalry forces to the battle, while the Ottomans deployed their heavy artillery and thousands of Janissaries. While the Ottomans were outnumbered, this time they were on the winning side, as the Qizilbash were no matched for the superior discipline and arms of the Janissaries.

Following the disastrous outcome of the battle, the Ottomans plundered the capital of Tabriz, as Ismail fled, wounded and having lost some swag (it, as well as many of his favorite wives, much of his treasury, and his entire harem was taken back to Istanbul. The swag remains there to this day). As Ismail descended down the dark road of miserable alcoholism, his invincible aura was shattered. The Qizilbash descended back down into tribal rivalries. Ismail’s successor, Tahmasp, saw the Qizilbash for what they were – an entrenched and power-hungry aristocracy, and quickly moved to replace them with Persian Bureaucracy. This effectively ended all Qizilbash influence on Iranian politics, though many still live in Iran and Afghanistan.

【译者注：正在翻译，这也太长了草……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Nader Shah began life as a member of the Afshar tribe in Khorasan. Nader was the only son in his family, his father being a herdsman who may have also made a coat. Unfortunately for him, his father died when he was thirteen, and the man who would become the Napoleon of Persia first became a man who survived by gathering firewood and selling it. At this point, his history wanders off (between the years 1707ish to 1724), and nobody knows what he was doing when Tahmasp II was chased out of Isfahan.

Somehow, Nader managed to become a figure of national importance, to the point that a very unseated Tahmasp and his Chief of the Army contacted him to try and convince him to aid their cause. Nader then discovered evidence that the said Chief of the Army was a traitor, and Tahmasp executed the man and appointed Nader as the new Chief of the Army. Nader then proceeded to retake Mashhad, destroy an Afghan army (and in the process of doing so, recruited another different Abdali Afghan Army), retake Isfahan, and send the last Hotakis running to their last seat of power of Kandahar. Upon retaking the city, he plundered it to pay his army.

Following this, Nader launched an ambitious expedition into Ottoman territories, and regained most of that lost during the Safavid succession wars. However, the Abdali Afghans chose this time to rebel, forcing Nader to suspend his campaign. While Nader was off saving his own brother’s ass, Tahmasp launched a disastrous campaign to recapture Yerevan (possibly because he grew envious of Nader’s successes). The result was that the recaptured territory was rerecaptured by the Ottomans. Nader was not happy with this, and in response he got Tahmasp drunk, embarrassed him in front of the Safavid court, and then forced Tahmasp to abdicate in favor of his son Abbas III in 1732.

Nader tried to rererecapture the lost territories by exchanging them for Baghdad, and then went to go actually capture Baghdad. This plan went poorly, as he failed to take Baghdad and got his army routed in the process, triggering revolts throughout Iran. He scrambled to retake the initiative, and managed to kill the man who defeated him in another much more impressive battle. After brokering an alliance with the Russians against the Ottomans, and winning several more crucial battles against the aforementioned foe, Nader finally succeeded in getting the Caucasus back under Iranian rule, and in putting down all the revolts.

Not long after this, Nader decided that it was time that he became the Shah, and had summons sent to large amounts of clergy, nobility, and militarymen of the nation to meet on some plains. There, he held a Kurultai in imitation of his heroes – Genghis Khan and Timur – and he was crowned Shah on 8 March 1736 (a date chosen to be especially fortunate, also in imitation of the two murderous conquerors that Nader idolized). Upon his ascension, he curbed Shi’ism’s more offensive practices in order to reconcile with the Ottoman empire (though in hindsight, reconciliation would probably have been more effective if he stopped starting wars with the Ottomans). Supposedly, he was indifferent to religious affairs, but he suggested a form of Shi’ism called Ja’farism, and had the Quran translated into a multitude of languages.

By 1738, Nader Shah finally conquered Kandahar, the last Hotaki stronghold, and noticed that the Mughal Empire was now collapsing… and yet quite rich. His own empire had been impoverished by his countless campaigns, so Nader invaded the Mughal empire on the pretext of hunting Afghan rebels. In a brilliant campaign, he utterly decimated the Indian forces (in some cases being outnumbered six to one).

Finally, at the Battle of Karnal he crushed the last Mughal army in less than three hours. He entered the city of Delhi posthaste, but a rumor had been started that Nader had been assassinated. Indians attacked and killed 900 Iranians. The rumor Nader’s death was greatly exaggerated, and a very upset Shah of Iran ordered Delhi to be sacked. 20,000 to 30,000 Indians were killed, and 10,000 were taken as slaves. The entire royal treasury was confiscated (including the Koh-i-Noor and Darya-ye-Noor diamonds, and the Peacock Throne itself). The booty was loaded on 700 elephants, 4000 camels, and 12000 horses. In short – he got a lot of money that would be useful in fighting even more wars with the Ottoman Empire.

Upon the return home, Nader decided to conquer all the Uzbek Khanates, annexing Transoxia, Khivia, Bukhara, and Kokhand. His reputation now very well known, and having extended Iran beyond even the farthest extent of the Safavids, Nader turned his attention to Daghestan. However, the Indian campaign was his height. After it, he began to sink slowly into despoticism and cruelty, building gigantic mountains of skulls on his following campaigns in emulation of Timur and Genghis. His paranoia raged and he blinded his own son as a result of his suspicion that he was behind a recent assassination plot. He began to execute nobles, and increasingly large numbers of enemies as his economy flailed. A flailing economy is no reason not to build a navy, and with it he conquered Oman.

Finally, Nader started one last war in an effort to take Baghdad – the first step in his dream of an empire from the Bosporus to the Indus. His military prowess had been spent though, and as new revolts broke out throughout the empire because of the war taxes, he was forced to make peace with the Ottomans. It was shortly before the Ottoman delegation arrived that he was assassinated. The plot included 15 conspirators who surprised the Emperor in the night, though the Shah managed to kill two of the assassins (though his final words were begging for his life). Nader was beheaded, and his empire descended into complete disarray, a state in which it would remain until the fall of the last Zand pretender and the ascension of the Qajar dynasty.

【译者注：正在翻译……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A Jazayerchi (literally meaning “Man armed with a Jazayer), was an elite heavy infantryman used by Nader Shah during his many campaigns. They were selected from the best of the Tofangchi, and granted a heavier caliber rifle known as the Jazayer (whose name is derived from the sound a wasp or a locust makes, apparently). However, the Jazayer was loaded using a horn rather than a paper cartridge, so it had limitations on loading speed. Thanks to its higher caliber though, it had the numerous advantages of range, force of impact, and accuracy – improving greatly upon the ineptitude of the standard tofangchi. Jazayerchi corps would train for several hours every day, with emphasis given to constant drilling and the finest equipment. While they were an infantry corps, they usually campaigned on mounts and would rarely fight as mounted troops.

During his rule, Nader’s Jazayerchi took on the most crucial objectives and tasks, oftentimes waiting for the enemy forces to draw close and then unleash a brutal volley of gunshot followed by evisceration by shamshir. This served to shatter enemy formation and order before cavalry went in for the kill. This strategy proved brutally effective, and Nader would usually command the Jazayerchi personally. During their incredible showing at the Battle of Karnal, it was noted that “an arrow cannot answer a Jazayer.” In addition to Karnal, the Jazayer proved their worth at the battles of Mihmandust, Murche-Khort, Kirkuk, Yeghevard, and Kars. In total, Nader had 12,000 jazayerchi at his disposal, in addition to 40,000 Tofangchi.
